header:
The talk schedule for the London Perl Workshop has been published,
the dates for YAPC::EU 2016 have been published,
and the call for papers for the German Perl Workshop came out.

Buddy Burden has published the next chapter of his Date and Time odyssey,
and Dave Rolsky declared that Perl 6 is fun, just in time for this issue.
Neil

entries.title: Senior Applications Engineer
entries.text: Uniregistry is looking for a talented and passionate engineer to build and maintain a world-class registry and registrar. This position requires the ability to analyze and implement elegant solutions to complex problems while contributing to the development of reusable components

entries.title: Supporting the Perl Weekly?
entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: Would you like to support the Perl Weekly? A Perl Job ad in the Perl Weekly, like the one above, will reach almost 6000 Perl developers. People like you, who are enthusiastic about Perl and not just use it as an add-on tool.
Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.
entries.title: NICEPERL's lists
entries.author: miguel_prz

entries.text: Doug introduces the ygrok utility, which is a new part of his ETL-Yertl distribution. It converts lines of plain text into YAML, so you can then further filter and process it.
entries.title: ygrok - Parse Plain Text into Data Structures
entries.author: doug_bell
alexey_melezhik
entries.title: Sparrow - tiny web monitoring tool
entries.text: The first alpha version of this web monitoring tool is now on CPAN as Sparrow, and also on github. Alexey is hoping that other people will join him in developing Sparrow and the SWAT web testing framework that it's built on.

entries.author: steven_haryanto
entries.title: Word-mode matching in tab completion
entries.text: A new completion mode has been added to Perlancar's Complete::Util module, which is used in a number of his tools, including lcpan.

entries.title: Perl 5 Porters Mailing List Summary: November 16th-22nd
entries.text: Perl 5.23.5 is now available, a bunch of bugs got fixed, and a bunch of other stuff was discussed.
entries.author: sawyer_x
david_farrell
entries.text: A quick reference style post that lists some of the problems you might encounter when trying to install Perl 5 modules, and what to do about them.
entries.title: How to install any Perl module

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: Gabor presents the most searched-for modules on MetaCPAN and search.cpan.org, though the figures are slightly dubious, since App::Netdisco comes out top on MetaCPAN!
entries.title: 20 most popular Perl modules

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.title: Generate random numbers in Perl with the rand() function
entries.text: Gabor shows how to generate random numbers in Perl 5, using the rand() built-in.

entries.title: Perl 6 is Fun
entries.text: Dave's been playing with Perl a bit recently, and shares some of the things he likes. In summary: "Pretty much everything I love in Perl 5 is still part of Perl 6, but almost everything I hate is gone too".
entries.author: dave_rolsky
naoum_hankache
entries.text: A new online tutorial for Perl 6.
entries.title: Perl 6 Introduction

entries.author: neil_bowers
entries.text: It's that time of year again! This is another pull request challenge, but for this one you need to do 24 pull requests in the first 24 days of December. You get to choose the github repositories, and they don't have to be Perl.
entries.title: 24 Pull Requests

entries.text: Ron has some failing tests in Gedcom::Date as the result of changes in DateTime. He wasn't sure how to go about sorting it out, so asked for help, and got a reply from the author of DateTime, Dave Rolsky. As a result Ron has released a new version and is waiting to see what CPAN Testers says. A great example of the helpful Perl community.
entries.title: Help needed updating Gedcom::Date
entries.author: ron_savage
joel_berger
entries.title: I'm Thankful for Perl
entries.text: Joel shares of the ways that Perl has impacted his life, and why he's thankful both for Perl and the community around it.

entries.author: brian_d_foy
entries.title: Larry Wall, Hero of the Revolution, the T-Shirt
entries.text: David Farrell and brian have created a t-shirt of Larry Wall styled after the iconic picture of Che Guavara. You can order yours on kickstarter, if you want one.

entries.title: Build an RPM in the Cloud
entries.text: Bigfoot shares some tips for people wanting to use Perl on Amazon EC2 instances.
Jeffery has written a script that will download all issues from a GitLab repo, since they don't currently provide a function for that.
entries.title: Perl script to backup GitLab.com project issues

entries.text: How to manage all your child processes, when your children kick off processes, and they in turn might kick some off. Frew presents two of the ways you can ensure that all of your descendent processes get cleaned up, and Tim Bunce pointed out another one in the comments.
entries.title: PID Namespaces in Linux
entries.author: frew_schmidt
sinan_unur
entries.text: Sinan spotted a test in a widely used module that was meant to be checking one thing, but was checking something slightly different. A great example of why code reviews are a good idea.
entries.title: What happens to tests that are never run?

entries.author: buddy_burden
entries.title: A Date with CPAN, Part 4: Construction Time Again
entries.text: Where Tolstoy had War and Peace, Buddy has Date and Time: he continues his series on developing new modules for handling dates and times.
Chad wants to clear up some of the confusion around Test::Stream, Test::Builder and Test::More. Key point: Test::More is not changing in any significant way.
entries.title: Test::More: Clearing up some confusion
entries.author: chad_granum

entries.text: Alexey has written an introduction to web testing using his SWAT framework.
entries.title: Doing testing in a swat way
entries.author: alexey_melezhik

entries.text: It's just under 2 weeks to the London Perl Workshop, which is on Saturday 12th December. Mark has now published the talk schedule, which includes a closing talk by Jonathan Worthington.
entries.title: The talk schedule for London Perl Workshop
entries.author: mark_keating

entries.title: Dates for YAPC::EU 2016 announced
entries.text: YAPC::Europe is going to be on 24th to 26th August next year. Reserve that space in your calendars, and start learning Transylvanian!

entries.author: steffen_winkler
entries.text: The German Perl workshop will be on the 11th and 12th March in Nuremberg next year, and now they're inviting talk submissions, for talks of 20 or 40 minutes, or lightning talks.
entries.title: Call for papers - gpw2016 - Nuremberg

entries.author: damien_krotkine
entries.text: This is part 2 of a series from Booking, talking about how they use Riak to store event data, and how they process it.
entries.title: Using Riak as Events Storage - Part 2

entries.text: I haven't read this book myself, but it sounds like not only a good book for teams using Git, but also about how teams can/should work together.
entries.title: A review of "Git for Teams"
The End of Dynamic Languages
entries.text: This blog post has been popping up all over the place, and has prompted a lot of follow-up posts (eg here and there). Elben believes that dynamic languages have had their day, and that typed languages like Scala and Haskell will eventually win out. When you've been programming long enough, you realise that proclamations of both outright victory or demise tend not to pan out.

subject: The schedule for LPW is out!
